unnormalised: A-levels maths results are out, and there's a buzz, especially around differential calculus! Loads of students in Delhi Public School, RK Puram, and even smaller schools in Guwahati are saying it was a tough paper. Apparently, many struggled with questions involving rates of change and optimization.
normalised: A-levels maths results are out, and there's a buzz, especially around differential calculus! Loads of students in Delhi Public School, R-K Puram, and even smaller schools in Guwahati are saying it was a tough paper. Apparently, many struggled with questions involving rates of change and optimization.

unnormalised: "Yaar, I messed up the related rates problem completely," said Rohan Sharma, a student from Mumbai. "I spent almost 45 mins trying to figure it out, but I couldn’t get the right answer. Think I lost around 15 marks there. My overall grade will probably be lower than 80% now."
normalised: "Yaar, I messed up the related rates problem completely," said Rohan Sharma, a student from Mumbai. "I spent almost forty five minutes trying to figure it out, but I couldn't get the right answer. Think I lost around fifteen marks there. My overall grade will probably be lower than eighty percent now."

unnormalised: Educators are chiming in too. Mrs. Iyer, a maths teacher from Chennai, noted, "The questions were designed to test a deeper understanding of the concepts, not just rote memorization of formulas. For example, there was one question on finding the minimum value of a function using the second derivative test. A lot of students just couldn't grasp that the function involved a complex fraction, and they just gave up on it after 30 min."
normalised: Educators are chiming in too. Missus Iyer, a maths teacher from Chennai, noted, "The questions were designed to test a deeper understanding of the concepts, not just rote memorization of formulas. For example, there was one question on finding the minimum value of a function using the second derivative test. A lot of students just couldn't grasp that the function involved a complex fraction, and they just gave up on it after thirty minutes."

unnormalised: Some are pointing fingers at the syllabus, saying it needs to be updated to better reflect real-world applications. "Why are we still learning about these old theoretical problems when we could be using calculus to model population growth or predict stock prices?" asked a Quora user under the name 'MathsGuru123'. The debate is definitely heating up online.
normalised: Some are pointing fingers at the syllabus, saying it needs to be updated to better reflect real-world applications. "Why are we still learning about these old theoretical problems when we could be using calculus to model population growth or predict stock prices?" asked a Quora user under the name 'Maths Guru one two three'. The debate is definitely heating up online.

unnormalised: One particularly tricky question involved optimizing the dimensions of a container given a constraint on its surface area. The volume needed to be maximized. Students say they knew the theory, but applying it under exam pressure was a different story. Some are even thinking of retaking the exam in Nov/Dec to improve their scores! The minimum grade to get into IIT Delhi is 90% so it is important to get the right score.
normalised: One particularly tricky question involved optimizing the dimensions of a container given a constraint on its surface area. The volume needed to be maximized. Students say they knew the theory, but applying it under exam pressure was a different story. Some are even thinking of retaking the exam in November or December to improve their scores! The minimum grade to get into I-I-T Delhi is ninety percent so it is important to get the right score.

unnormalised: Adding fuel to the fire, there are rumors of a leaked question paper circulating on Telegram. While authorities haven't confirmed anything, the whispers are making students even more anxious. One thing's for sure: differential calculus is the topic on everyone's minds right now.
normalised: Adding fuel to the fire, there are rumors of a leaked question paper circulating on Telegram. While authorities haven't confirmed anything, the whispers are making students even more anxious. One thing's for sure: differential calculus is the topic on everyone's minds right now.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, coaching centers like FIITJEE and Aakash are offering crash courses to help students prepare for the retake, promising to cover the entire syllabus in just 2 weeks. The fee? Around ₹25,000. Talk about capitalizing on the chaos! It's not worth taking the crash course unless you failed the section because 25,000 rupees is a lot!
normalised: Meanwhile, coaching centers like F-I-I-T-J-E-E and Aakash are offering crash courses to help students prepare for the retake, promising to cover the entire syllabus in just two weeks. The fee? Around rupee twenty five thousand. Talk about capitalizing on the chaos! It's not worth taking the crash course unless you failed the section because twenty five thousand rupees is a lot!

unnormalised: The CBSE board hasn’t released any official statement yet, but students are hoping for some leniency in the grading. Perhaps a curve of 5 points could help ease the pain. Let's wait and see how this all unfolds! The pass or fail grade depends on getting a good grade in this section so its crucial they grade generously.
